Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Novel Piezoelectric Device Fabrication Using Digital Projection based Additive Manufacturing

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this Grant Opportunity for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) award is to solicit fundamental knowledge and understanding in fabricating piezoelectric devices with controlled shape and functional characteristics in order to develop an innovative and cost-effective additive manufacturing process for the nation's biomedical imaging industry. In the planned research, both the green-part fabrication for desired accuracy and resolution and the heat treatment procedure for required piezoelectric properties will be studied. The process modeling and related controlling methods will be established for the piezo-composite based additive manufacturing process. The effects of the addition of Sol-Gel solutions and related heat treatment procedures will be evaluated to understand their relations to piezoelectric properties. The property measurement and experimental validation will be performed with industrial partners to verify the capability of the additive manufacturing process.

Novel piezoelectric devices used in electronics, photonics, sensors and actuators require more complex shapes and better precision for improved performance. Research results of this GOALI award will provide knowledge and understanding to meet the critical need of improved accuracy and resolution control as well as the densification control in the piezo-composite based additive manufacturing process for piezoelectric device fabrication. A globally competitive biomedical imaging industry will contribute to the nation's economy and healthcare, and new piezoelectric devices with better quality and lower manufacturing cost will benefit consumers and the society. The project will also enhance the infrastructure for ultrasonic imaging research and education at the University of Southern California by providing a digital fabrication method with increased shape flexibility. Graduate and undergraduate engineering students and mid-career professionals will benefit through classroom instruction and involvement in the research. Outreach programs to high school students will be utilized to increase minority participation. The designed hands-on learning experience and exposure to advanced manufacturing applications will increase the interest of domestic students in science and engineering.

ProgramReference.Text: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this research was to understand the use of an additive manufacturing process in fabricating piezoelectric devices with controlled shape and functional characteristics for biomedical imaging industry. Piezoelectric ceramic materials, such as Lead Zirconate Titanate (PZT) and Barium Titanate (BaTiO3), have been widely used in medical diagnosis, energy harvest, non-destructive testing and many other applications. The piezo-composite based stereolithography process offers the ability to fabricate piezoelectric devices with complex geometry that are not possible with traditional manufacturing methods.  In this research project, the use of such an additive manufacturing process was studied including both green-part fabrication for desired accuracy and resolution, and heat treatment procedure for required piezoelectric properties.

A number of significant results were found throughout this research and have been disseminated for the additive manufacturing community. First, a bottom-up projection based stereolithography process by integrating slurry tape-casting and a novel two-channel sliding design was developed to fabricate piezoelectric composite material with high viscosity and low light penetration depth (Figure 1). Models of the process parameters that affect the thin layer recoating and the separation mechanism during the bottom-up fabrication process were established. Two journal papers based on the study results have been published. The capability of the developed additive manufacturing process in fabricating various structural and functional ceramics has been demonstrated (Figure 2).

A second set of results was obtained after investigating the effects of different piezoelectric material compositions on the physical properties of the sintered components. The piezoelectric property of the fabricated green parts can be greatly improved by a post processing process involving both debinding of organic polymer and sintering of ceramic particles (Figure 3). Various dielectric and ferroelectric properties of the sintered samples were measured and compared with the bulk piezoelectric materials. In addition, ultrasonic transducers were fabricated based on the sintered components with their acoustic performance tested (Figure 4).  Two journal papers based on the study results have been published. The finding is significant as it provides a method to fabricate novel piezoelectric devices with predictable properties. The project concluded by demonstrating the capability of additive manufacturing in fabricating novel functional ultrasound transducers including controlled focus distance and novel array shapes, and subsequently testing the fabricated transducers in animal eyeball structure study (shown in Figure 5).

The broader impacts of this project are shown through the opportunities provided to undergraduate and graduate students, including three female students.  Through funding for this work, two graduate students completed their Ph.D. dissertations within the grant period. One of them became a faculty member and will continue the line of the research work with his future students. Several undergraduate students conducted research under this grant, and gained hands-on experience with additive manufacturing machines and laboratory testing equipment. The constructed prototype additive manufacturing system was also used in the demonstration to industrial visitors and high school students in various outreach programs over the grant period.

The developed slurry based stereolithography process was used in manufacturing various composite materials including the suger-based composite for foam materials that can be used in tissue engineering, and dielectric composite with complex shapes for novel capacitors. In addition, the developed additive manufacturing process was used in fabricating other ceramic materials such as calcium phosphate. Working with our collaborators in medical school, custom 3D-printed calcium phosphate scaffolds have been tested for regional gene therapy in bone graft scenarios to heal critical sized bone defects (refer to Figure 6). Two journal papers and a provisional patent application have been published based on the study results.

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The objective of this research was to understand the use of an additive manufacturing process in fabricating piezoelectric devices with controlled shape and functional characteristics for biomedical imaging industry. Piezoelectric ceramic materials, such as Lead Zirconate Titanate (PZT) and Barium Titanate (BaTiO3), have been widely used in medical diagnosis, energy harvest, non-destructive testing and many other applications. The piezo-composite based stereolithography process offers the ability to fabricate piezoelectric devices with complex geometry that are not possible with traditional manufacturing methods. In this research project, the use of such an additive manufacturing process was studied including both green-part fabrication for desired accuracy and resolution, and heat treatment procedure for required piezoelectric properties. A number of significant results were found throughout this research and have been disseminated for the additive manufacturing community. First, a bottom-up projection based stereolithography process by integrating slurry tape-casting and a novel two-channel sliding design was developed to fabricate piezoelectric composite material with high viscosity and low light penetration depth (Figure 1). Models of the process parameters that affect the thin layer recoating and the separation mechanism during the bottom-up fabrication process were established. Two journal papers based on the study results have been published. The capability of the developed additive manufacturing process in fabricating various structural and functional ceramics has been demonstrated (Figure 2). A second set of results was obtained after investigating the effects of different piezoelectric material compositions on the physical properties of the sintered components. Various dielectric and ferroelectric properties of the sintered samples were measured and compared with the bulk piezoelectric materials. In addition, ultrasonic transducers were fabricated based on the sintered components with their acoustic performance tested (Figure 4). Two journal papers based on the study results have been published. The finding is significant as it provides a method to fabricate novel piezoelectric devices with predictable properties. The project concluded by demonstrating the capability of additive manufacturing in fabricating novel functional ultrasound transducers including controlled focus distance and novel array shapes, and subsequently testing the fabricated transducers in animal eyeball structure study (shown in Figure 5). The broader impacts of this project are shown through the opportunities provided to undergraduate and graduate students, including three female students. Through funding for this work, two graduate students completed their Ph.D. dissertations within the grant period. One of them became a faculty member and will continue the line of the research work with his future students. Several undergraduate students conducted research under this grant, and gained hands-on experience with additive manufacturing machines and laboratory testing equipment. The constructed prototype additive manufacturing system was also used in the demonstration to industrial visitors and high school students in various outreach programs over the grant period. The developed slurry based stereolithography process was used in manufacturing various composite materials including the suger-based composite for foam materials that can be used in tissue engineering, and dielectric composite with complex shapes for novel capacitors. In addition, the developed additive manufacturing process was used in fabricating other ceramic materials such as calcium phosphate. Working with our collaborators in medical school, custom 3D-printed calcium phosphate scaffolds have been tested for regional gene therapy in bone graft scenarios to heal critical sized bone defects (refer to Figure 6).
